print_settings.Notes:: You will need to print 2 18_tooth gears ans 2 15_tooth gears.

description.text:
This is an extruder born of necessity.

I had hundreds of hours of (mostly) successful printing with a simple, direct drive extruder using a brass Mendel style gear. Sometimes, especially when using a small nozzle (0.2 mm) the extruder had a hard time pushing the filament. Using a small diameter gear (Mendel) there where no skipped steps, but filament grinding. So I decided to reinvent the extruder and dispose of the filament tensioner bearing and replace it with another pusher gear. If the filament would be pushed form both sides, it will result in less to no grinding.

Due to the bearing sizes available to me, I moved from the Mendel gears to brass mk10 (clone) gears.

This is the 4th iteration of this project and the first one that is easy to built and assemble.
It works reliable as of 30 print hours ago, but I still consider this a work in progress as further testing is required.

As a personal note, doing this, I learned to design gears (Pitch Diameter, Pressure Angle, etc.). The internet is a wonderful resource and only if you don't want to learn something you can't, otherwise, there's no excuse.

After lots of design and testing of this extruder (I was on the 3rd iteration), I saw that I'm not the only one and certainly not the first to approach the dual geare extruder problem. But I think mine is smaller and hopefully better then the others.

The extruder:

To make the second gear work counter clockwise and in sink with the main gear I needed some kind of clockworks or belts. To keep it as small as possible I decided on gears. The clockworks is somewhat separated from the extruder part to prevent filament shavings from entering between the gears.

For extra power and accuracy, I made a 3:1 reduction gearbox. Not wanting to generate a fresh pair of herringbone gears, I taken some from the beautiful NSTT Extruder by Paciente8159.

Part list:

3x m3x30mm screw
2x m3x20mm screw
2x m3x8mm screw
1x m3x16 screw
1x m5x60mm screw (internal hex head) - preferably with partial thread
2x m5x100mm screw (to be cut for axles) - preferably with partial thread
1x m5 nylon captive nut
4 x m3 nut
some washers
6x 695ZZ 5X13X4 bearing
2x 625zz 5x16x5 bearing

https://youtu.be/sLyT0wXdCTk

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

All the parts are printed in PLA with a minimum of 3 solid walls.
The gears are printed with 100% infill. I would recommand using nylon for the gears like Taulman Nylon Bridge.

  • You will need to print 2 18_tooth gears ans 2 15_tooth gears.

Step 0.1

After you print the parts, make sure they are clean (especially the gears !!!). Use an x-acto knife or other model making, precision cutter.

Step 0.5

After cleaning the gears, take one of the small m3x3mm headless screw from the mk10 gears (they work just fine with one) and screw it in the holes on the 15 tooth pla gears. Do this for both gears.

Place 2 small 695ZZ 5X13X4 bearings in the two 18 tooth gears.

Cut one long m5x100mm screw in 2 parts. The one with the hex head has to have a 50mm long shaft and the second one 30mm. File/grind this 2 parts carefully to make a key way like the one on the nema17 motor shaft. I used a bench vise and a proxxon hand tool (like a dremel) with a small grindstone (safety glasses here !!!)

Cut a second one to make a 20mm long rod needed on step 6 (no key way here).

Step 1

Press the small herringbone gear on the shaft of the nema17 motor. The height is given by the big gear in step 4

Step 2

Mount the gearbox base to the motor and fix the small tapered head m3x8 mm screws.

Step 3

Glue in place (red arrow) a small m3 washer. This will keep the m5 screw head from rubbing against the pla body directly. Think of this as an axial pressure bearing.

Use PTFE spray here to lube the inside of the case.

Step 4

Place the M5 bolt inside the big herringbone gear and spray it with PTFE grease. Put it in place. Align (if needed) the small gear.

Step 5

Push a 625zz bearing in the base of the gearbox top assembly and screw it in place. Use 2 x 20mm m3 bolts to fix it through the gearbox base in the nema17 motor. Use a small tapered head m3x16 and an m3 nut to fix the corner.

Step 6

Place one of the small 15 tooth gear on the m5 bolt fixing it with the small m3 headless hex screw recovered from the mk10 gear. Do not over tighten this screw as it's easy to strip the plastic thread. The height is given by the next part.

Put the 5mm diameter 20mm long rod in the marked hole. This would be an axle for one of the 18 tooth gears.

Step 7

Place one of the idler 18 tooth gear on the shaft. Use some kapton tape to make it snug if needed.

Step 8

Put the dust cover in place and mount the mk10 extruder gear (not in picture).

Step 9

Put the top cover in place. Press a 625zz bearing in the hole. Fix this part in place using 2 m3x30 screws in their holes (red arrow). Place 2 m3 nuts in their respective holes (green arrow) and tighten everything.

Step 10

Assemble the secondary axle as in the picture. Use one of the screws from the mk10 gear to fix the pla gear. Do not tighten everything in place as you will need to adjust the finale position.

Step 10 Step 11

Assemble the arm using a m3x30 screw and nut and two 695ZZ 5X13X4 bearings.

Step 12

Mount the arm using the m5x60 screw. You will need to place the second idler gear in place. Fix the screw on the back with a washer and a m5 Teflon captive nut.

Now you can adjust and tighten all the screws on the 15 tooth gears and the mk10 extruder gears). Note the two 15 tooth gears need to slide by each other but not touch (0.5mm should be enough between them).

Carefully grease the plastic clockwork gears with PTFE grease, not touting the brass gears. You don't want grease on the metal extruder gears that come in contact with the filament

Step 12 Step 13

Put a m3x30 screw through the hole in the arm with a spring, washer and nylon nut as in the picture. The nylon captive nut is there to precent the screw to fall from it's mount when the arm is open. Place an m3 nut in the corresponding hole in the extruder body.

Force screw the PTFE tube connector in the hole on top to attach the bowden tube.

You are done !!

Design

This extruder is designed form scratch in Solidworks.

yes, that's professor Lawrence Krauss talking about quantum mechanics in the background :)

title: Nexus 5x Phone Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A fairly basic case for Google's Nexus 5x phone. There's a few different designs on here (including another one of mine), but they all tend to be very flat to the surface of the phone, and don't provide much screen protection.

This model wraps more aggressively around the front of the phone, and to the curves of the phone. The upside is that it provides more protection -- both to the camera bump and to the screen and corners. The downside is that there's absolutely no way you can print it with PLA or ABS or any other rigid filament and get it on the phone. This really has to be printed with TPU or another flexible filament.

I suspect if you use your slicer to stop printing after the layer at 10.10 mm, it might fit on a phone even with PLA or ABS, but I haven't tried it. If someone does, and it works, let me know and I'll update this.

There are two models uploaded. The "Flat Bottom" version has thicker bottom edges. While the one that hugs the bottom curve prints fine in PLA, I can't get unsupported TPU to print at that angle, thus the flat version. Upside, though -- slightly more protection along that edge, I suppose. If you're some kind of printing magician or can print TPU with disolvable supports, that one looks better. But its really nearly impossible to print.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

.20

Notes:

A couple notes -- I have printed this in both PLA and TPU without supports, but getting the bridges to print in TPU means having your settings really dialed in. If you don't want to waste filament discovering you can't, print some bridging tests and make sure your printer can do it, or use supports.

The print I'm using on my phone was printed with 3 top layers, zero bottom layers with a honeycomb infill to give a pattern to the back. You can print however you want for the look you want, though.

title: Egg Drop Challenge Winner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As we had a challenge at the university, I designed and printed out this cartridge in a tube.
We won :)

To find out how it works exactly, please read in the section "How I designed this" below.

The Shpere and the Main Body should be printed with the thread at the bottom.
The 2 Inner parts (cartridge) with the thread at the top.

Print the Bumper with Filaflex or another flexible material and with no bottom layers, a low infill (cube-pattern) and one perimeter.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1 - 0,3 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You may scale everything to 1000%.
Print the threads at 0,1 mm layer height or even less. The rest does not really matter, I printed all non-functional parts at 0,3 mm.

The Sphere should be printed almost at 100% to ensure that the centre of gravity is located at the bottom. You can also place something heavy at the inner surface of it, but remember that the overall weight should not be too high, as it falls faster then.

I have chosen sawtooth-threads this time as I wanted to see if it works with that as well.

You may screw the threads together a few times, file it a bit, then it will slide easily.

Glue the Bumper right at the centre onto the Shpere and let it dry properly.

I designed this with Autodesk Inventor.

How it works: There is a little gap between the Cartridge and the Main Body. This ensures that the Cartridge can slide easily and that air can flow around it.
At the point of impact, The Cartridge with the egg in it (put some cotton or similar around the egg inside the cartridge) wants to fall down towards the ground now. But the air underneath it can only escape through the small gap between the cartridge and the tube. This acts now like a simple air-damper.
For the hard and first impact itself, the Bumper is made for. Made out of elastic material, it will absorb parts of the energy, depending of the infill-percentage.
For the last hope, there is a kone made inside the Sphere. Look closely at the pictures I made. If nothing helps, the cartridge will be stopped no later than there.
The fins were made to give the whole thing a rotatary motion while falling. This ensures a higher stability and will decrease the falling speed eventually.
In uni I had a challenge to drop an egg from 3 metres without braking it. The provocation was, to use organic material only. As PLA is made out of cornstarch, I began designing :)
A challenge for eggs that survive a drop of a few metres.
You can allow organic material only as well, but this is up to you.

comments.text: I love the air damper concept.  Years ago we tried a similar system using hydraulics instead of pneumatics.  the problem was finding a material with the right viscosity, and we eventually settled on mayonnaise....  It was messier than your system for sure, but that was in days before 3D printing.

title: AudioPlayerCase cnc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This simple case features some barrel-hinges and magnets to securely keep shut. The form is intended for a cheap, but very popular Chinese audio player I got of Amazon.

This build was done from 6.3 mm beech plywood using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft with a 3 mm spiral toothed end mill. A vacuum machine bed simplifies the process significantly, because you don't need to camp the material, thus it stays pretty flat. Further more I don't need tabs on the parts resulting in less sanding.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

Very simple base with 60mm diameter. I also included a small lip.

Resumen

Diseño de piezas para montar el robot DYOR. El diseño de las piezas está pensado para una base de 12x12 como máximo.

Descripción de las piezas:

  • DYOR Ratoli Cap i DYOR Ratoli Cos se ensamblan con cola y forman la parte frontal con una cara de ratoncito. Los ojos son els sensor de ultrasonidos, la nariz el zumbador y la boca el panel de LEDs.
  • DYOR Base1 y DYOR Base 2, se utilizan para crear la base del robot, donde se ensamblan los motores y hay un par de ranuras para acoplar la parte frontal de ratón.
  • DYOR Base 3, es una cavidad que se debe encolar a la base y es donde se situa la bateria powerbank
  • DYOR sensor llum, és una pequeña pieza que se utiliza para sujetar el múdlo seguidor de línias.

Componentes electrónicos

El diseño esta pensado para que se pueden ensamblar los siguientes componentes:

  • Sensor de ultrasonidos: HC-SR04
  • Zumbador
  • Pantalla de Leds 8x8 max 7219
  • Servos para las pinzaso brazos TS90M
  • Servos FS90R para ruedas de 60mm
  • Módulo para seguir línias TCRT-5000
  • Alimentador (powerbank) USB de 2000mAh
  • Placa Arduino Nano v3.0 + placa Expansion I/O para Arduino Nano

Explicación vídeo

En el vídeo se muestran las diferentes piezas del robot impresas con la impresora UP Mini 2. Tambien se puede ver el ensamblaje de las piezas que forman el robot. Para la unión se ha utilizado cola termofusible. Al final del vídeo se puede apreciar el robot con todas las piezas electronicas montadas y conectadas

Diseño de la electrónica con Fritzing

A traves del siguinete link se puede descargar el diseño para editarlo con fritzing
http://fritzing.org/projects/dyor-remix

Más informacion sobre el curso "Diseña, fabrica y programa tu robot" UPV Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

title: 28mm Stone Texture for Terrain Building Foam Surfaces

description.text:
This is a printable texture that you can use to press into cheap dollar store foam core to create a rock texture. Bunched up tinfoil is traditionally used for this but I wanted something a little more solid that wasn't as wasteful.

I started with this rock texture image:
http://www.sharecg.com/v/9604/related/6/Texture/Rock-Face-Texture

I converted the image to 24-bit BMP using Paint.Net
https://www.getpaint.net/

I used Sketchup Make 17.2 with the following extensions to create a 3D mesh from the black and white image.

https://extensions.sketchup.com/content/tt_lib%C2%B2
https://extensions.sketchup.com/en/content/bitmap-mesh

Update

I can press it into foam to make a stipple pattern but the detail is far too small. I'm going to make a new item using the "Bumpy" script for Sketchup.

Auto bed reglé est le Bilinéaire car je trouve l'UBL trop fastidieux, mais cela est mon avis....

title: Richardson Philippine Guerrilla Gun Receiver Jig

description.text: Richardson Industries Philippine Guerrilla Gun 12 gauge plug and receiver jig. The plug is designed to use a 1/8" track spike with a 12-32 thread filed down as a firing pin. The receiver jig is for drilling a 3/8" hole all the way through the 1" black iron pipe in the proper location for the plug. For modeling purposes only. Not intended to be used as a weapon. PLA will not hold up to the pressure of a shotgun shell.

remixed_from.author: Justblair
remixed_from.title: Parametric Model Rocket Fin Alignment Tool

description.text:
This is a remix of justblair's awesome fin alignment jig. The original had a few minor problems which I've fixed (most of these affected larger jigs in particular):

  • fin width is now calculated correctly (it was previously half a tube diameter off)
  • the fin tab ends now respect the wall thickness setting
  • the brim width is now configurable
  • the cylinder smoothness variables have been modified from the $fn method to the $fs/$fa method
  • the center cutout is now properly based on the jig height

Aside from the scad file so you can create your own jigs, there's STL files for several common rockets:

  • Estes Jetliner
  • Estes Curvilinear
  • Estes Mosquito
  • Estes Mini Der Red Max
  • Estes Der Red Max
  • Quest Navajo AGM
  • Madcow Formula 75

The Estes Jetliner jig is special, it has one fin removed and an added support for the wing. Align the bottom of the jig with the bottom of the body tube, and slide the wing fully into the slot and it should be aligned properly.

The Madcow Formula 75 model is where I discovered most of the small issues with the original model. This is certainly the largest of the set that I've included here and has a beefy 4 mm thickness. It gives a lot of support to the fiberglass fins and results in perfect fins for the rocket.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These things are one profile going straight up, so use the tallest layer height that you can accurately print. With a common 0.4mm nozzle, 0.3 mm layer height should be great. If you happen to have an E3D volcano, crank that height up and have at it.
The most you should have to do with this is clean up strings inside the fin slots depending on material and printer settings. Running a popsicle stick through the slot is generally good enough.
• use 2x M6 nuts and glue part A and B together

title: 6-Piece Burr Puzzle - 42-Piece Set of Notchables Pieces
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Full 42-Piece Set of Burr Puzzle Notchables Pieces.

The name of the pices is base on the Rob's Puzzle Page definition (http://www.robspuzzlepage.com/interlocking.htm), and shown in the pdf file available in the files.

You can play it in 2 ways :

  • Free Mode
    Pick up 6 pieces of your choice and try to assemble them to form a cross. A solid burr (with no void) has a total value of 40.

  • Guided Mode
    Select a puzzle in the list and try to assemble the 6 given pieces.

Fusion 360 file available at http://a360.co/2sYFVfV

description.text:
This is a bearing roller stand that I created to go in my dry box. The filament spool sits on top of the rollers for smooth pulling during printing. The sled is made to snap together, I recommend using ABS since the rods that hold the bearings need to flex a bit when snapped together. PLA is likely to break during assembly. I got the idea of snap fitting the two halves from other parts I saw on thingiverse, however I drew up my own design.

Use 8x24x8 bearing rollers.

Made to fit 100mm(radius) 200mm diameter filament spools without making them any taller while sitting in my dry box. The other roller I tried made it sit up high not allowing me to close the lid on my dry box.

print_settings.Notes:: You might need a raft or a brim if the end of the launch guide doesn't adhere well to your bed.  If using PLA, you need lots of cooling since this is a small part that stands fairly tall.  If it comes out looking terrible, it's likely a cooling problem.

description.text:
This is a parametric launch guide. By changing the rail setting between true or false, it will output either a 1010 rail guide or a launch rod guide. The rail_* values could be modified to fit other sized rails, otherwise they are the correct dimensions to fit 1010 rail currently. The rod_* settings change the size of the rod you're using, and then there's basic settings for the guide's length and the rocket diameter.

Epoxy doesn't always adhere well to 3D printed plastics, so use appropriate adhesives and ensure that you have a good bond before launching. I've used this model on D motor sized rockets up through level 1 high power models with no issues.

Notes:

You might need a raft or a brim if the end of the launch guide doesn't adhere well to your bed. If using PLA, you need lots of cooling since this is a small part that stands fairly tall. If it comes out looking terrible, it's likely a cooling problem.

title: Laser Module Air Flow Deflector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An accessory to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982844

While laser cutting paper, the airflow from the laser module likes to blow cuttings around which occasionally will block the laser beam. The airflow also can lift the paper off of the focus plane This attachement which screws onto this (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982844) laser mount via accessory screw holes to deflect the airflow from disturbing the target. Unfortunately also inhibits fire extinguishing feature of laser module (the blowing air). Use at your own risk. There is enough room between the module and the deflector to get your fingers in to focus the laser.

Suggest printing with supports

Unique 3D printed battleaxe. Designed off of the Dwarven Axe from Skyrim. Post-Print Assembly Required.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200-400 micron

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

For unique look, print the blade edges at 400 micron. Infill will determine weight and rigidity. set to your own comfort level.

Print files 0 - 3 (the handle components) twice.
Print files 4 - 7 (the head components) once each.

Step 1: Combine the Halves

I used E6000 as the adhesive to assemble the axe. I did a light sanding to give the E6000 something to grab onto (this is optional, the natural grain work well on its own). I usually clamped the two halves together and let sit overnight to fully cure (Seen Below).

Step 2: Assemble Pieces

I then sanded and filed around the pegs and slots that connect the handle pieces and head together. I put a layer if E6000 in the slot and snuggly fit the pegs in. This step can be completed all at once since the pegs should already be held in by friction. A loose fit will can cause a curve to set in the handle or head. Make sure all sections are parallel as well.

Step 3: Sand and Prime (if necessary)

Once all of the pieces were assembled. I sanded any bubbles that formed and filled and severe cavities I found in the piece. Everything receives a light (220+ grit) sanding before being coated in XTC-3D (https://www.smooth-on.com/product-line/xtc-3d/) mixed with aluminum powder. This took a few tries to get right so make sure to test it on a sample piece first if you're not comfortable. Because My head was not grey I did I light paint "prime" in a gunmetal grey to help mask the bright colors. I also went over the head twice in areas that needed to cover seams or still had light color shining through.

Step 4: XTC-3D

I did this in sections starting with the head of the axe and handle. I left the pummel clean so that I could hang the piece from a hook and string to dry with out touching anything. This step must be completely quickly as XTC-3D has a very quick working time before it starts to cure. Once it starts to stiffen, you need to create a new batch. The mixing ratio with metal powder is 2A:1B:1Powder (equal amount Part B and Metal Powder). Powder is to be premixed into A before mixing A to B. Let it dry completely before doing any finish work (should take a couple hours)

Step 5a: Metal Finish Work

There are many routes you can take to get a finished metallic look. The easiest and most common is to go over your work with fine steel wool or 600 grit sandpaper. These are still abrasive so be careful not to stay on one spot too long or too hard. For a weather, used look consider sanding with heavier grit in quick erratic motions. I used varying degrees of 60, 150, and 220 grit sandpaper to make it look like it took some hits. Always finish with 600 grit or steel wool to give the shiniest natural finish.

Step 5b: Rust/Weather Painting

Using a combination of Grey, Silver, Black, Copper, and Gold acrylic paints, I added weathered details to the axe in any cracks and crevices. This gives the axe a rusted look while also hiding any print lines the XTC-3D couldn't get to. Use a rag between and after any application. The goal isn't to paint the entire piece but to have bits of paint in the pits, scratches, and valleys of the part. The mixes and effects are as follows:

Grime/Dirt:
Matte Black (wipe quickly, possibly water down as well)

Dirty Rust:
Matte Black and Metallic Red/Copper (mix in varying ratios for a different, more natural look)

Fresh Rust:
Metallic Red/Copper and Metallic Gold (Mix a good amount of Red to Gold, the Gold gives it a more vibrant rust look"

Metallic Highlight:
Silver and Gunmetal Grey (Dab lightly on tip of brush and quickly brush edges and features)

General Additional Metal:
Gunmetal Grey (This is for helping cover up any excessive dark marks left by the black to red paint.)

Step 6: Leather Grip

I went to the fabric store and bought Faux leather for the grip. I place a couple drops of black paint in a rag and dragged the leather side through it. This gets a little black paint in the deeper parts of the leather while wiping away all the excess. This gives it a used look and also darkens the leather a bit.

To attach, I put a little bit of E6000 at the starting point and tightly wound the leather around. I tried to keep the leather tight but not stretch it. I made my gaps about a fingernail width apart but that was so I had enough strip that I could cover the whole handle in one go. At the end, I used two brass furniture nails and E6000 to secure the bottom. Everything in between the top and bottom are held by friction and tension.

Step 7: Finishing Touches

My final touches were a light polish with Mag Aluminum Polish and to clean up the edges of the leather, I used a lighter and singed the edges quickly (don't want to melt the plastic underneath).

description.text:
This parametric launch pad can be setup to hold any size rod with any size legs. I used it with 3/4" legs to hold a 1/4" launch rod. Buy some dowels for the legs, cut to whatever length you like, insert a launch rod, and put some sort of blast shield on, and you're good to go.

Note that this is a fairly light weight pad, so for heavy high-power rockets, you might want to add some sand bags or something to hold it steady.

This pad has been used to launch a variety of rockets up through level 1 high power successfully.

description.text:
This parametric motor retainer uses the "Poor man's openscad screw library" found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796

The settings in the scad file are adapted to my printer, aside from the dimensions at the top, you may need to adjust the "fudge_factor" setting until you get an appropriate fit on your body tube and a well-functioning thread.

Use this at your own risk, if you do not have sufficient layer adhesion, this part will not retain your motor when the ejection charge goes off. Ensure that your printed part is sufficiently strong before using it in flight! If the threads are too loose, they can slip off the retainer ring, so be sure your thread clearance is tight enough as well. The clearance should be as tight as possible while the threads are still functional.

Note that not all adhesives work well with printed plastics! Be sure you have a strong bond between the retainer ring and the motor mount tube before you use it for flight.

description.text:
In general, tube fins are the easiest thing in the world to assemble, but why not make it even easier? I recommend gluing the first fin tube to the body tube and lay it flat on a table to ensure good alignment. Let the glue set a bit so it's secure, and then glue the rest of the tubes on all willy-nilly and slip the jig on to hold it all in place to dry. Note that you should ensure the jig will slide on easily and hold the tubes securely before you do any gluing. Your printer and slicer may have different tolerances than mine, so size adjustments may be necessary.

This parametric tube fin jig was created to help assemble the Quest Totally Tubular rocket, but everything is parametric so adaptation to rockets like the Estes Super Neon XL or similar rockets should be pretty easy.

description.text:
Betty Rubble, from the Flintstones cartoon show by Hanna-Barbera.

The Flintstones cartoon takes place in a romanticized Stone Age setting, depicting the lives of the Flintstone family and their best friends and neighbors the Rubbles.

Betty was modeled in proportion to my Fred, Wlima, Barney and Dino models.
Fred: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1361894
Wilma: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2345526
Barney: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2385276
Dino: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1473207

No supports are required. If you have the proper filament colors, no painting is needed.

The model is 260mm tall.

Enjoy, and I hope you have a "Yaba Daba Do" time printing this!

Printing and assembly tips

1-As with most of my models, no supports are required.

2-Be sure to clean any first layer squish if you have any problem joining parts. The parts should fit nicely when printed cleanly.

3-I did not require any rafts or brims for any of the parts, use your discretion for your machine.

4-Be aware, there are some small parts.

..
Assembly tips:
1-The eyebrows are inserted with the flat side from the print bed into the head and the wider edge towards the middle.
2-As a purist I usually load each part separately, however the left and right eye_blacks are interchangeable.
3-The eye_whites are inserted into the head with the hole for the eye_blacks slightly off-centered towards the middle.
4-The dress bottom bulges out a bit in the back, do not put this part in backwards!
5-Refer to the assembly diagram for putting the model together. The model is meant to be glued.

description.text:
This parametric shock cord mount will let you make a mount to fit any sized body tube. I normally secure my shock cords to the motor mount, but if you're retrofitting an existing rocket with a new cord, this might be just the thing you're looking for.

Note that many adhesives don't work well with printed plastics, so test your adhesive on a scrap piece of tube before trying it on your actual rocket. If the glue doesn't hold up to the ejection charge's force, you're going to have a bad time. Good layer adhesion is also important, give the loop a good tug to make sure it's going to hold up before you rely on it in flight!

description.text:
We use baby gates in our house to contain our dogs.

Being the flawed human I am, I lost a bag full of those little screw/pad things you use on the corners to press against the door frame.

So I had to design some from scratch. I figured while I was at it I had always wanted to mount them across a diagonal space requiring some "L Brackets" so I would design one of those as well. I did co-opt the wonderfully design knob handle from the bearing press I printed last month.

The angled brackets are used when you need to traverse a space with pillars or non-flat surfaces on the sides (like going diagonal, or mounting against a stair that uses banisters.)

These use 5/16" threaded rod and normal 5/16" nuts.

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

Ultra 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

This was with ABS, but should be fine with most materials.

Step one - attach nuts.

I use a small dab of superglue when I put the nuts into the brackets and tensioner. (Rev 2 I will probably shrink the hole a tiny bit to make a snug glue-less fit.)

Step two - Cut and attach rods

I cut some 5/16th threaded rod to around 6" and screwed it into the brace nuts

Optional - Add padding.

To avoid scratching a painted surface I then added felt padding to the contacting surfaces. I used the same peel adhesive felt pads that you usually use for furniture feet on hardwood floors.

Design notes.

Most notably I used the great knob in that Bearing Press thing, then modified it for the most part.

The L bracket I cooked up from scratch.

All work was done in TinkerCAD.

title: FR sensor mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Use this Thing to hold a Vishay TCST1103 photo interrupter with a small PCB to the top of your Prusa i3 MK2 to sense when you have run out of filament. The large hole is for 1.75 mm filament, the small hole is for the light from the photo interrupter.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Notes:

Nothing special, whatever will give you good layer adhesion with minimal distortion. I used MatterHackers orange PLA at 0.2 mm layer height.

Electrical

Solder the TCST1103 sensor with 3 resistors and an LED as shown in the schematic. I used a piece of perfboard that I trimmed after soldering. The LED will be off when the sensor is blocked. I terminated the wires with a Molex 5057-9403 connector that will plug into the endstop sockets.

Hardware

Ream the filament hole with a 2 mm (5/64 inch) drill bit and check that the small cross hole is unobstructed. Load filament through the mount and into your extruder. This will help ensure proper alignment. I used a pair of really small wood screws in pilot holes to hold this to my extruder, and hot PLA to hold the sensor down.

Software

Hex file available: https://github.com/RabidStatic/Prusa-Firmware-with-FR.git

The script by allen.d in this link will setup an isolated preconfigured Arduino environment.
http://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/software-f13/one-click-script-to-modify-and-compile-mk2-firmwar-t2858.html#p22243

I uncommented the line #include FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SUPPORT in my variation file that is renamed to Configuration_prusa.h. I also changed the pins.h file to use the Y-Max pin as my FR_SENS pin and changed Y-Max to -1 to disable it.

After testing I found I needed to invert the logic. In Marlin_main.cpp change "if(READ(FR_SENS))" to "if(!READ(FR_SENS))"

Compile your firmware and pick up the .HEX file from:
C:\Users[your user name]\AppData\Local\Temp\build[long string of numbers and letters].tmp\Firmware.ino.hex

Upload with FirmwareUpdater packaged with your Prusa drivers.

author: RabidStatic

description.text: This is the "elbow" for a book scanner project. I am making a book scanner using easy-to-get-and-assemble parts from the local hardware store (aside from the electronics), and I did not want to use plastic for the platter that presses the pages together. This allows me to use glass sheets from the local hardware store, without having to bend. It will also allow me to make the book scanner portable (quick disassembly into a briefcase) for use on family history books, libraries, etc.

Used OpenSCAD

Designed in OpenSCAD, slowly worked out use of variables to make it more customizable.

comments.text: This is incredibly interesting. When you get it complete, please provide a link to the finished project.
comments.author: samwyse

comments.text: I went with a 105 degree angle to allow the book to open far enough, but not break the spine on the book.  This should allow it to be used on old, valuable books without incurring damage.  However, if you want to adjust the angle (e.g. 120 degree), just edit the OpenSCAD file and change the angle, then re-generate the STL file for printing.
comments.author: silverhawk02

comments.text: You are right about using an angle wider than 90 degrees to avoid reflections of the image between the two plane. I am following the easy book scanner construction using PVC, but would love to see something even more portable with 3D printing.

description.text:
Four* elephants (by ashdodge) carry a map of the Discworld. Diameter 150 mm.
You should print the model upside down. I forgot to enable supports at my first print, this worked surprisingly well.

*To compensate for the absence of the turtle, there is a fifth elephant. Remember that the old legends tell of the fifth elephant which once carried the discworld, too, but then slipped off Great A'Tuin, cometed around, hit the surface in Überwald and became so the reason for the rich fat mines.

Vier* Elefanten (von ashdodge) tragen eine Karte der Scheibenwelt. Durchmesser 150 mm.
Das Modell sollte mit den Füßen nach oben gedruckt werden. Bei meinem ersten Druckversuch hatte ich die Stützkonstruktionen nicht aktiviert, das klappte erstaunlich gut.

*Als Ausgleich für das Fehlen der Schildkröte gibt es einen fünften Elefanten. Die Scheibenwelt wird zwar nur von vier Elefanten getragen, doch alte Legenden erzählen vom fünften, der einst von Groß A'Tuin abrutschte, als Komet in Überwald einschlug und so zur Quelle für die dortigen Fettminen wurde.

This is a tablet mount for an XBox One Controller. Specifically it was designed for an 8" NuVision TM800W610L Tablet but It might work with other 8" tablets as well. I also have a version that will work with an iPhone 6+ with a slim case for use with SmartGlass .

The XBox controller has the audio port open. There is also a hole to keep the grip from pressing the sync button, which I found to be a problem with another grip on this site.

The idea was that this $80 Windows 10 tablet (though it could be found much cheaper), when paired with a USB Wireless AC adapter and a Bluetooth XBox One S controller becomes a perfect device for Steam and XBox One streaming. Plus it can do some lightweight gaming and emulators on its own. It isn't quite a Nintendo Switch, but it isn't too shabby for ~$150.

Assembly

I recommend a 1 1/4" #8 screw to assemble the two pieces.

I also recommend putting electrical tape over where the grip touches the controller and tablet to prevent scratching.

description.text:
This upgrade mounts the extruder motor on the top of the printer.

Why Did I Design This?

My original aluminum Z-Carriage was wrongly bent and I redesigned it (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2425237). To avoid that the filament touches the Z-axis leadscrew, I chose this position because I haven't used the original handle a single time.

Printer:

TronXY X1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm (2/10)

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I'll probably never learn to avoid black for upgrades....

Printer

The part was designed to be easily printable on a TronXY X1. It can, however, be printed with any printer.

Orientation

The upgrade can be printed in the original orientation but I recommend laying it down on the flat side.

Instructions

To successfully mount the upgrade on top of the European Standard 2040 extrusion, grab the two original screws and fix the holder with them as seen in the pictures. The extruder motor gets put in from behind, and the extruder tightens it up similar like it was before.
I used tinkercad for the whole design process.

title: Large and Small Accessory Adapter for Original Weber Genesis 2007 thru 2016
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It drove me nuts that none of my grill utensils fit on my new 2016 Weber Genesis gas grill so I created this adapter to fit both large and small grill accessories. Best printed in a silver (I've been using ABS).

Note that this will fit the original Genesis which sold from something like 2007 - 2016.

Mid to late 2016+ Weber introduced Genesis II (two) which has a completely different utensil hanger so this won't work on Genesis II.

title: Wall mount for Alfa Tube-U Wifi antenna

description.text:
This is an antenna wall mount to easily mount/dismount the Alfa Tube UV Wifi - USB antenna.
See here for the product.
The adapter is attached to the wall of the caravan. Antenna slides into the mount from above.

Printed in ASA (UV-resistant equivalent for ABS).
Infill 15%, printed with a 0,6mm nozzle and a layerheight of 0,48mm.
4 shells, 4 top- and bottomlayers

Mounting :
Use 4mm self tapping stainless steel screws and a butyl based kit.
Best location is, of course, at the top where the antenna has a clear view.

This replaces the standard top plate on TJ Williams' frame. I designed it in AutoCAD 123D and included the design file in case anyone wants to modify it or make a version for the other Gremlin frames.

P.S. Thanks Flite Test, keep up the awesomeness!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/clsRq4sSU8I

TR
Nemli bölgelerde yaşayanlar ve evde sürekli koşuşturan çocukları olanlar iyi bilir ki filament makarasını toz ve nemden korumak biraz sıkıntılı olmaktadır. Bu yüzden olabildiğince modüler bir şekilde bu filament kutusunu tasarladım. Gelişmeye açık ve öneriniz olursa mesajlardan iletebilirseniz memnun olurum.

EN
Everyone knows who live in moist places and have children that run continuously in the home that protecting the filament spool from dust and moisture can be really difficult. So I designed this case as modular as it can be. It is prone to improvements and I'll be glad if you have a word and text me in the messages.

Gerekli Malzemeler (BOM):

TR
Çeşitli boylarda M3 vida ve somun
111mm boyunda 8mm çubuk
2 adet 608zz rulman
Kutuyu yazıcıya asmak için uygun boyutta m5 veya m6 civata ve t somun
Şeffaf asetat kağıdı (50x72)
Opsiyonel:
İhtiyaç halinde PC4-M6 pnömatik rakor ve PTFE tüp
Eğer nozülün aynı zamanda filiitre görevi de görmesini istiyorsanız uygun ebatta süngeri nozülün kubbe kısmını dolduracak şekilde yerleştiriniz

EN
You need various lengths of M3 screws and nuts.
8mm steel rod in 111mm length (material doesn't matter)
Two 608zz bearings
M6 or M5 bolts and t nuts to hang the case to the 2020 or 3030 aluminum extrusion. Transparency printer paper (50x72),
Optional:
PC4-M6 Pneumatic Fitting and proper size of PTFE tube
Proper size of sponge if you want to use the nozzle also as a filament filter. You can put the sponge inside the dome of the nozzle.

Ahşap Plakalar (Wooden Plates)

TR
Kutunun iç ve dış kısmına 5mm kalınlığında ahşap plaka kullanılmıştır. Kesim için dxf dosyası dosyalar kısmında mevcuttur. Yazıcıya takılan kısımdaki plaka kutuya vidalarla sabitlenmektedir. Kapak görevi görecek olan dış plaka ise 3 adet klips yardımıyla kutuya sabitlenir.

EN
Wooden plates in 5mm thickness are used for the two sides of the case. For cutting the plates relevant dxf files are added in the files section. Base plate is fixed to the case with m3 bolts and nuts. Lid is fixed with three clips.

Şeffaf Pencere (Transparent Window)

TR
Transparan asetat kağıdı ile pencere kapatılarak filament makarasını görebilmek için bir kısım yapılmıştır. Eğer gereksiz olduğunu düşünüyorsanız Drum3 yerine Drum4 basınız.

EN
A transparent window is added to the walls of the case to make the spool visible. If you don't want this option you can print Drum4 instead of the Drum3 model.

Hava geçirmezlik (Air tightness)

TR
Hava geçirmezlik için kapak kısmının kenarlarına conta görevi görecek bir lastik yapıştırılabilir. Ben pencere ve kapı kenarlarına yalıtım için yapıştırılan lastik süngerlerden kullandım. Ayrıca kullanım esnasında kutu içine nem alıcı silika jel poşetleri bulundurulabilir.

EN:
For air tightness you can glue a rubber or something along the edges of the lid. For removing the moisture you can put silica gel capsules inside the case.

description.text:
This upgrade replaces the original metal Z-carriage that also carries the extruder motor.

The reasons for this design were both the not properly bent original z-carriage and the fact, that the raw filament touched the Z-leadscrew.

Additional Things

The original design does not carry the extruder anymore. Therefore, it needs to be placed in a different spot, like on the top of the Z-axis extrusion, where another design of mine comes handy (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2425144).

However, I've added an adaption of the design that still has the extruder motor mounted on the carriage (read below).

I also recommend adding some extra stabilization to the whole Z-axis compound (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275654)

T8 Version

Thanks to inspiration from the community, I also adapted this model to fit a T8 lead screw (8mm in diameter) and the corresponding nut.
BUT I didn't have the chance of testing it myself because I haven't upgraded my lead screw yet! If you print it, please let me know whether it worked out. It should, but you can never be sure...

Version with Extruder Holder

Thanks to inspiration from the community, I furthermore published both versions with a Extruder Motor Holder. As the motor is quite heavy, I chose to make this part 10mm thick, which is about 6-8mm thicker than other versions. Therefore you need to provide longer screws.
Attention: Again, I have not yet had the time for testing it out myself. If you print it, please let me know if it does or doesn't work. It should, as it's just a copy of some of my working things, but you never know for certain...

Edits 3/2/18

  • As the version for the T8 leadscrew is now on Thingiverse for over half a year without complaints, I removed the "BETA" from its description. However, it will still be in the file-name.
  • I added an extruder motor holder for each version.
  • As there are now versions with extruder motor holders, I had to rewrite parts of the description.

Printer:

TronXY X1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm (2/10)

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The part was designed to fit onto the print bed of the TronXY X1 printer. It can, however, be printed with any machine.

Steps for Mounting

Replacing the Z-carriage is very intuitive, namely, print all necessary parts, dismantle the current Z-carriage with the extruder and mount the new stuff. Use zip ties to hold the cables in place.
I used tinkercad for the entire design process.

title: Ultimachine Spool Spacer (formerly thing:7907)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE: Re-posting someone else (TheRuttmeister)'s thing that he had been taken down (formerly thing:7907), because it should be up. Not doing this out of disrespect for him or his right to take it down, but when I'd downloaded it before it was under the CC-BY-NC-SA license, so I have the right to share it again here, and choose to (rather than just hide away my own copy and hope I don't lose it). Sharing it under the same license.  
His description:  
A spacer that allows you to mount a spool of plastic from Ultimachine on an 8mm rod.  
Updated version added, now had bolt holes to allow you to clamp the bearings in place (mine kept falling out).

These instructions are from TheRuttmeister's original item:  
Print 2 spacers.  
Press fit the 2 608 bearings. Add some M3x15 bolts and nuts to help retain the bearings.  
Insert the 2 spacers into the spool.  
Stick the spool on the 8mm rod.  
You'll need to supply your own 8mm rod holding device! (Something that hangs off the back of your cupcake might be nice).

author: theengineer96

description.text:
If having the filament spool on the bottom of your SmartAlu is not the best option for you (for instance if it's not accessible enough, or if you need the extra height to print some very tall piece), then this spool holder is probably what you need! :)

The cone and spacer pieces are the same as the ones from my SmartRapCore spool holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023607), so if you already have this one, you can re-use them, and simply print the vertical support piece.

You'll need two of the cone piece, and two 608ZZ bearings to insert in each cone.

You'll also need an M8X100 bolt and an M8 ending nut to make the axis for the spool holder it self, and two M4x12 bolts and hammer nuts to install the whole thing on the printer's aluminium structure.
A tiny printable tripod.

Print the part.
Add 3 pieces of M5 thread.

print_settings.Notes:: Also used Palette from Mosaic Manufacturing for dual color.
print_settings.Printer:: Type A Machines 2015 Series 1

description.text:
There are lots of fidget spinners out there, but so far I have not found many 608 bearing replacements for those like myself who prefer an all 3DP route.

This 608 size bearing has a 3D printable design that works better than trying to make a ball bearing version. It spins pretty good (https://youtu.be/I2v80PHl3BM) and may do better with some lubricant.

In addition, I have made some 608 bearing size holders for weights: one accepts 4x US dimes and the other 4x US pennies. Print the part twice and they should clip together firmly and fit snug into any spinner designed to accept a 608 size bearing. There are plain versions as well as a set with lightning bolts. For the bolted ones, you need the "bolted" part and the "bolt" part for each to print in multicolor (I used a Palette for the one shown). I suppose you could also just print the "bolted" part and it would see through to the coins. Might look cool too, but I have not tried.

The two fidgets shown are this one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275352
and this one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078189
and were each printed on a Formlab Form2 printer in Tough V3 resin for durability.

Enjoy!

This page will be left for legacy purposes and I will still answer questions if posted. From now on, all my future projects will feature exclusively on www.MyMiniFactory.com.
My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill. Sorry for any inconvenience.

No rebel fleet or Imperial star ship should be without the humble Gonk droid, so here one for everyone to have. Is approx. 85mm high and comes in two parts with a connecting pin. Full assembly STL has been added for anybody wanting to add or change anything. The orientation of the STL's above is never right for anything I upload for some reason so before printing just check the orientation is correct. For my other Star Wars models see my collection - http://www.thingiverse.com/lilykill/collections/star-wars Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases. If interested, join my group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/design-to-print/topics where I aim to help anybody with anything I can with modeling or assembly like this design.

remixed_from.title: Freetrack Head Tracking IR Clip for HD555/595

title: Freetrack Head Tracking IR Clip for HD555/595 mirrored

description.text:
I needed a headset tracker similar to t00fatt's but I needed it to be able to mount to the opposite side of my headphones. I did not bother printing the clip because I attached mine to a different type of headphones using velcro, but I included a mirrored version in case anyone else needs it. If you want more information and assembly instructions, I suggest you look at t00fatt's listing since this is exactly the same except reversed.

I do not recommend printing the diffusers if you are using wide-angle IR diodes. I have wide angle diodes and I found that the diffusers reduced their viewing angle and brightness, but if you have standard diodes your results may differ from mine.

Replacement tank printed in PETG using vase mode. Transparent filament highly recommended in order to see juice-holes.

Since e-juice bottles are made of PET I assume it should be ok to expose this filament to these conditions. I therefore don't recommend to use other filaments due to possible interactions (juice eating plastic, plastic dissolving into juice, etc.) and I give no guarantees whatsoever that PETG is safe for this purpose either.

Printed like stated the part isn't leaking and sturdy enough to do the job assuming the print went perfectly. Dimensions fit for me but might need adjustment.

title: TPS bracket for 1.6 L Mazda Miata using Kia TPS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a bracket to install a variable TPS onto your 90-93 NA 1.6L Mazda Miata using Kia part number 0K24718911 from various early 2000s Kia vehicles. This is to be used with aftermarket ECUs only. The stock ECU neither befits from this mod, nor can it interpret a VTPS. The stock Miata TPS connector is the same as the KIA connector, so this sensor plugs right into the Miata harness with no mods.

You will need:

  • Bracket
  • VTPS (interchange part nos: 0K24718911, 5S5504, TH291, TPS 291, and others)
  • Qty 2 of each: m4x14mm long screws, m4 nuts, m4 washers

The hardware is used to attach the TPS to the bracket. The OEM Mazda TPS screws will work to attach the bracket to the throttle body. If youd like to replace them, they are also M4x0.7 pitch, and about 10mm long.

You will need to wire your ECU as shown in the diagram and as follows:

  • Ground is already done through the factory harness.
  • 2L needs to be connected to your 5V out or reference voltage of your ECU
  • 1N needs to be connected to the TPS signal in of your ECU.

If you have a plug and play ECU that doesn't utilize an adapter harness between the ECU and factory harness (such as the Megasquirt PNP or Adaptronic) you may need to swap the 1N and 2L wires in the harness, at the TPS connector, or at the ECU connector, depending on the pin-out of the ECU you are using.

This must be printed out of ABS, Poly-carbonate, Nylon or any other "high temp" filament. PLA will melt in an engine bay.

Flyingbear P902

description.text:
Love 'em or hate 'em, Harbor Freight stocks some sweet deals for cheapskates like me. This screwdriver set has been really useful over the years, but I loathe the brittle plastic tray because:

  • it cracks if you look at it.
  • the bits cannot be removed using normal adult human phalanges.
  • bits inevitably fall through the cracks, leading one to believe they're lost, when in fact they're hiding underneath, and are (ironically) now accessible using normal adult human phalanges.

Here's a better one.

The tray pictured is my first version with vertical bit holders....but the lid won't close. Ugh.

I redesigned with angled bit cells, but as of yet I've been too lazy to print it. It should work though.

I'm just a star trek fan and tried to create this badges by myself. I was useing some pictures and photos that I found in the internet, to model these. Use the following magnetes to attach the badges on your shirt:

4 disc magnets 4 x 1 mm for each badge
https://www.amazon.de/Unbekannt-100-Neodym-Micromagnete-Zylinder/dp/B00CLPZYF8/ref=sr_1_3?s=officeproduct&ie=UTF8&qid=1502533505&sr=1-3&keywords=magnet+4x1

and

1 sew-in magnets for the shirt
https://www.amazon.de/Scheibenmagnete-Einn%C3%A4hen-quadratischer-PVC-H%C3%BClle-Haftkraft/dp/B072PRHJBL/ref=sr_1_1?s=kitchen&ie=UTF8&qid=1502533698&sr=1-1&keywords=magnete+zum+einn%C3%A4hen

To integrate the disc magnets to your print, generate the g-code and check the first layer level that close the holes for the magnets. Open the g-code file with text editor and search for the first Z"layer level". Write one line before the text: "M600 E0 L0 ;" and save the file.

If you use for example a resolution of 0.1 mm, the first closing layer will be 1.4 mm. Look for the first Z1.4 in the g-code and write one line thereover M600 E0 L0 ; (don't forget the dot comma). The command M600 stands for filament change pause. It should look like:

G1 X123.204 Y103.192 F7200.000 ;
M600 E0 L0 ;
G1 Z1.400 F7200.000 ;

If the last layer befor closing the holes is finished, the printer pause. Now, put the magnets into the holes and watch out to have identical pole direction of all magnets! Keep also in mind the pole of the counter magnet on your shirt.

If you push a button to continue the print, be aware the printer extrude some filament before printing. Get sure that no filament stuck on the extruder.

After printing, you can prime and paint the badges.

I'm printing with a prusa Mk2 and had no problems with the magnets on the print bed.
Be aware to not use magnets on your chest if you have a pacemaker! You can instead print the normal model (without magnets) and use a double-sided tape.

title: Modern Salt Shakers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A set of two ergonomic salt shakers, easy to grip and easy to pour. I say salt, because I prefer my pepper ground fresh, so I don't recommend anyone use pre-ground pepper ever! PSA: If you use pre-ground pepper, switch over now! The flavor difference is huge.

The holes are 2mm, that should be enough for a good pour, although you may need to use a poker needle to clear the holes fully after the print. The caps are sized to fit well, but if they're too tight, just twist them back and forth a few dozen times until they wear in.

The larger shaker allows a great deal of control over the amount of salting depending on its orientation, so whether you need to salt just a little or salt a whole table of barbecue quickly, it'll do the job!

The smaller shaker has a good pour, not as much control though, but a small foot print.

Recommended print settings: 2.8mm walls for durability and looks (this will make it solid, but still allow for infill in places like the cap body)

Warning: Print in a food safe material.

comments.text: The large salt shaker has no tolerance set in the cap, there's no way to screw the cap to it, it's just too large to fit.
comments.author: innomind

comments.text: There is tolerance, it's just very small so that it doesn't leak granules of salt. I've already printed a couple. You just have to tighten then loosen the cap a few dozen times until it wears a little bit, then it will screw on easier.

description.text:
This is a mod to the original D-Bot extruder backplate by spauda1
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065

The original design worked fine for me but I found that the gap between the extruder gear and the filament feed hole occasionally allowed the filament to spill out of the gap and create a birds nest.

I've recreated the extruder and moved the entrance to the filament feed much closer to the extruder hob gear, I've been using this modded part for a few weeks now and the problem has pretty much gone away.

title: Threaded nut for 12V Car power adapter

description.text:
I purchased a 12V cigarette power recepticle for my DIY Exercise bike, but managed to loose the nut to hold it in place.. so.. to Fusion 360 we go.

The threads is isometric with a pitch of 1.5mm, but Fusion only had threads for M28 and M30 and this thing is somewhere inbetween.. I tweaked the standard library a bit and managed to come up with a thing that actually worked. It's a bit tight, so maybe expand by a few % in X and Y directions before printing.. otherwise, PLA is cheap and you can do it again :)

print_settings.Notes:: too

description.text:
I once found these straight rod brackets in our local recycling yard and It turned out they fit perfectlly for this bison tube I had and I turned it into a geocache. I did have 2 sets of the brackets, but I gave one set to a friend in New Zealand, thinking that I would never need them myself and that new ones probably were easy find, right? WRONG.

After almost 5 years of service, someone nicked the geocache from where it had been hiding and so I was in a bit of a bind. The bison tubes are roughly 14mm in diameter (some, a bit bigger) and the only brackes I can find now are eithr too large (19mm inner diameter) and won't fit in the altoids tin or very very expensive to get (I might have find some in the UK that charges a hefty fee in shipping).
So... maybe I can 3D-print this thing? YES.

.. albeit, the overall diments are a bit bigger due to the need for slightly thicker walls and all (maybe I will experiment with pitch 1 threads.. hah), but it will get the job done :)

These can be used for their actual purpose too, although they might not hold too much weight.

Only STLs for now, but if anyone is brave enough to try out the Fusion 360 project for it (first day using it), please let me know. If used for their axtual purpose, the emtpy hole in the thread stud on the bracket end should probably be made solid to give a bit more strength.

description.text:
I created this helper to make sure my endstop jumpers were plugged into the correct pins on my Raspberry Pi. I use Octoprint to sense when the filament runs out. This was designed for my use, and I am sharing this in case someone else might find it useful.

The Makerbot 1.2 style endstop I got requires 3.3vdc, ground, and an I/O pin. This forces you to use Pin 1 (3.3vdc), Pin 6 (ground), and Pin 7 (GPIO 4).

There are many filament endstops cases and mounts available on Thingiverse.

I recommend you make sure the pins line up correctly before connecting the wires to your endstop. (I hooked up the pins in the wrong order once and it rebooted my Pi, I'm lucky I didn't wreck anything!)

comments.text: I'm in the process of printing two of these -- One with a height of about 90mm and the other at 85% of that.  I mirror-flipped the smaller one in Simplify3d.  I'm using Hatchbox wood PLA and will sand, stain, and varnish them, using a different stain color for each.  I used 4 layers and 35% infill to give me a little more heft and a little more thickness to work with during the finishing.  I used the fine setting for layer thickness to reduce the "stepping" on the rounded top of the head and also to reduce the amount of sanding I'll be doing.  Printing time for the big cat was about 3:45 and the smaller one will be about 2:45 using a Hatchbox Alpha.  These will be a gift to my mother.

comments.text: The scar forms because the layer changes at the same point every time. When I printed with 10% infill, the printer changed layers at a different point each time, so the 'scar' was spread out over the entire cat in little indentions that were hard to notice unless you inspected the cat closely. You could try with 1%, and that might work, no guarantees at that low of an infill though.

remixed_from.author: Area51
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2/S Adaptor for 40mm Silent Fan

title: Prusa I3 MK2/MK2S Adaptor for 40mm Fixed Screws

description.text:
I printed up the original version of this fan adapter by Area51 twice, thinking I had messed something up in my settings. It turns out the fan screws were carved out at M2.5 rather than M3. So I modified the step file, carved out the fan screws at M3, and added in threading in Fusion 360 to make my fan screws catch.

When wiring the new fan to the old adapter, I also suggest using the Noctua extension cable that comes with the fan. This allowed me to unplug and adjust the fan wire as needed, making it extremely easy to troubleshoot.

This is a quick rendering of my book scanner plan frame concept. Please know that this is simply a concept (do not print this). It will be easier to simply build the frame using PVC pipe from your local big box hardware store and cutting boards from somewhere like bed bath and beyond. Pivot joints will be the hardest to do in a way that will last, but you can use skate bearings on a rod threaded through the upper frame, heim joints, or even offset hinges.

I would also suggest adding counter weight to the back of the upper frame until to get a weightless unit including the platten.

Had an old parrot ar drone 1.0 laying around for a while so I decided to play around with it a little and build it up for my 10 yr old daughter to play around with. I found this file on thingiverse and completely remixed it. The bottom plate was backwards and the cam mount was a little thin so I completely re drew it all up in cad and added a battery holder to the top mount. Takes two 3mm x 25mm screws and two 3mm by 30mm screws. I put the two smaller screws to hold the bottom frame to the cross member center and two longer screws to attach the top piece.

title: MPCNC-C (23.5 mm conduit) Spool Hook with Filament Guide

description.text: I was tired of my spool constantly unraveling, and hanging it on some of the extra conduit seemed too simple of a solution to stick with permanently, and thus I designed this! It's based on the shape of the 'Flashforge finder spool holder with filament guide' by kvasbo (Linked in the 'remixed from' section). It holds onto the conduit well enough, and keeps the filament nice and taught while printing. I included the SolidWorks files to allow for easy modification for different size spools or conduit. I'm using it to hold the 1.2 kg 3DMars filament spools, and it hasn't dipped yet! The image above is of an earlier version, the newest version has a thinner filament guide arm, as visible in the .stl files.

title: Ikea Renlig dwti60/aka Hotpoint Dishwasher top basket rear stop

description.text:
I recently repaired our dishwasher but when i put it back together the rear stop on the dishwasher was missing. So I designed this (for printability it is missing part of the support but should fit fine. I will update once printed.

I printed in PETG with a glass transition temperature of 85C should be ok on a max 70 cycle. The only load is actually when you are unloading or loading the dishwasher so actually should be fine.

title: CNC Z axis with Dremel 3000 mount

description.text:
This is the Z axis for my custom build CNC machine. It has mounting holes to add a mill, the files to mount a Dremel 3000 are included.

What do you need?

  • 4x 12mm bearings with a 3mm hole
  • 4x 10mm M3 screws
  • 6x 15mm M3 screws
  • 6x 30mm M3 screws
  • 7x 10cm Makerbeam beams (2 of them are cut to 7cm)
  • brackets to assemble the frame (mine are custom made)
  • 2x 10mm aluminium pipes cut to a length of 190cm
  • M5 threaded rod (175mm)
